name: Remove Element
title: Remove Element
content:
Given an integer array nums and an integer val, remove all occurrences of val in nums in-place. The order of the elements may be changed. Then return the number of elements in nums which are not equal to val.

Consider the number of elements in nums which are not equal to val be k, to get accepted, you need to do the following things:

  • Change the array nums such that the first k elements of nums contain the elements which are not equal to val. The remaining elements of nums are not important as well as the size of nums.
  • Return k.

Custom Judge:

The judge will test your solution with the following code:

int[] nums = [...]; // Input array
int val = ...; // Value to remove
int[] expectedNums = [...]; // The expected answer with correct length.
                            // It is sorted with no values equaling val.

int k = removeElement(nums, val); // Calls your implementation

assert k == expectedNums.length;
sort(nums, 0, k); // Sort the first k elements of nums
for (int i = 0; i < actualLength; i++) {
    assert nums[i] == expectedNums[i];
}

If all assertions pass, then your solution will be accepted.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [3,2,2,3], val = 3
Output: 2, nums = [2,2,_,_]
Explanation: Your function should return k = 2, with the first two elements of nums being 2.
It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned k (hence they are underscores).

Example 2:

Input: nums = [0,1,2,2,3,0,4,2], val = 2
Output: 5, nums = [0,1,4,0,3,_,_,_]
Explanation: Your function should return k = 5, with the first five elements of nums containing 0, 0, 1, 3, and 4.
Note that the five elements can be returned in any order.
It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned k (hence they are underscores).

 

Constraints:

  • 0 <= nums.length <= 100
  • 0 <= nums[i] <= 50
  • 0 <= val <= 100

discussion_posts.name: niamlaylor
discussion_posts.content: This is a vert poorly written question. Clarity is key in coding. Bad requests get bad code!

discussion_posts.name: Code_Surgeon
discussion_posts.content:
LeetCode: It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned K
Also LeetCode :
output [2, 2, 3]
expected [2, 2]

discussion_posts.name: HiCode
discussion_posts.content:
For this input it is giving output as wrong answer.
[3,2,2,3] and val=3
My answer is 2
It is saying expected answer is [2,2].
Now I am confused that I have to return and array or the count of elements (i. e. and integer).

discussion_posts.name: tristancrudge
discussion_posts.content:
One of the worst questions on the platform hands down. 

Says: Return k
I: Return k

Result: Error expected an array
I: Change to an array

Result: VALUE NOT EXPECTED


Get out

discussion_posts.name: steve1031
discussion_posts.content:
Answer does not seem to be correct for this case.

Input
nums =
[0,1,2,2,3,0,4,2]
val =
2

My output
3, [0, 1, 3, 0, 4] but expected answer is [0, 1, 4, 0, 3]

discussion_posts.name: ishbar
discussion_posts.content:
I really dislike whoever made this, and the other similar problems.

`nums[:] = [x for x in nums if x != val]` works, but (for whatever reason) `nums = [x for x in nums if x != val]` does not. 

This is really confusing to me when the problem description states 
"Do not allocate extra space for another array. You must do this by modifying the input array in-place with O(1) extra memory."

discussion_posts.name: DyuldinKS
discussion_posts.content: The most unclear description I\'ve ever seen on leetcode. Especially for an easy task. Wasted time.

discussion_posts.name: centroid
discussion_posts.content:
[python]
"Case2" IS WRONG!
========
nums = [0,1,2,2,3,0,4,2]
val = 2
Output = [0,1,3]      # stop checking elements after getting 3 instead of 4
Expected = [0,1,4,0,3]
=========
Correct expected nums is [0,1,3,0,4]! so testcase2 is incorrect!
